para: This option sets a speed limit for your track. The filter will discard any point that would require you to have moved at a speed greater than this limit to get there from the previous point.

This is a powerful tool for cleaning up "GPS zingers" â€“ those moments where your GPS receiver momentarily reports a position far away from your actual location and then jumps back. For example, if you are recording a walk, you could set this to a reasonable walking speed like 3 meters per second. Any point that would imply you suddenly moved at 50 m/s will be thrown out.

Example: You are cycling and have a max speed of 15 m/s (54 km/h). You could set:
gpsbabel -i gpx -f my_ride.gpx -x kalman,max_speed=15 -o gpx -F my_ride_filtered.gpx
The units are always in meters per second.

The pre-defined profiles use the following values: 'walking' (2.0), 'running' (10.0), 'cycling' (30.0), 'driving' (50.0), and 'flying' (300.0). If you are using a profile, you do not need to set this option unless you want to override the profile's default.
If you are using a profile, this value is set automatically, but you can override it here.
